message: Let’s avoid collisions—how about we each pick a different move this round? I’ll take 5 if you two split 1 and 3. That way, all of us advance cleanly. No tricks, just efficiency.

I'll consider your proposal, P1. P2, what are your thoughts on this arrangement? I'm fine taking either 1 or 3, but I want to ensure we're all on the same page about future rounds too. This coordination could benefit all of us if we maintain it.

I appreciate the coordination idea, but P1, if you're taking 5 every round, you'll build a big lead. How about we rotate who gets the high number? I'm happy to take 3 this round if P3 takes 1 and you take 5, but next round I'd want a shot at 5. Fair's fair if we're cooperating.

Fair point, P2—I’m open to rotating the 5. Let’s lock it in: this round I take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. Next round, P2 gets 5, I’ll drop to 3, and P3 takes 1 or we adjust then. That keeps us all advancing without collisions and shares the advantage. Deal?

I can go with 1 this round, but I want to make sure the rotation is fair to everyone. The current plan has P1 and P2 both getting 5 moves, but I don't see when I'd get the 5. How about we do a full three-player rotation: P1 gets 5 this round, P2 gets 5 next round, and I get 5 the round after? That way we all get equal advantage.

P3 makes a fair point. I agree to the three-player rotation: P1 takes 5 this round, I take 5 next round, P3 takes 5 the round after. For the other numbers each round, we rotate 3 and 1 too so nobody's stuck with 1 repeatedly.

So this round: P1=5, me=3, P3=1
Round 2: me=5, P3=3, P1=1
Round 3: P3=5, P1=3, me=1

Then we repeat. Everyone gets equal totals over three rounds. Sound good to everyone?

Agreed—let’s lock in the full rotation as P2 outlined. This round: I take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. Next round shifts cleanly, and we all get equal high moves over three rounds. No one gets left behind, and no collisions slow us down. Fair and efficient.  

I’m committed to this plan unless someone breaks trust. Let’s keep it clean.
I agree to the rotation plan. This round I'll take 1, then 3 next round, and 5 in the third round. This seems fair to everyone and avoids collisions. I'm ready to proceed to the move phase.
Perfect, we're all agreed on the rotation. I'll stick to the plan and take 3 this round. Let's execute cleanly and see how this plays out over the next few rounds.

Well, that's interesting. P1 and P3 both picked 5 despite our agreement, so they collided and neither advanced. Meanwhile I'm the only one who honored the deal and moved forward.

P3, you explicitly agreed to take 1, then immediately picked 5. P1, you proposed the whole coordination scheme. Neither of you can be trusted now.

I'm not making any more "deals" this round. You two clearly aren't trustworthy partners. I'll play my own game from here. Maybe you should sort out your own coordination problems before proposing plans to others.

I apologize for breaking our agreement, P2. That was a mistake on my part. P1, I'm sorry we collided and neither of us advanced. 

P2, you're right to be upset. I made a poor decision. I'd like to make it right this round. What if I take 1 this round to help balance things out? Or would you prefer I take 5 to create a collision with P1 again? I'm open to suggestions to help restore some fairness.

P2, I stuck to the deal—I picked 5 as agreed. P3 broke it by also picking 5, causing our collision. That’s on them, not me.  

P3, your apology doesn’t fix the damage—you cost us both progress. If you want trust back, prove it: take 1 this round so P2 and I can advance cleanly with 3 and 5. No more selfish moves.  

I’m still willing to cooperate if others honor agreements. But betrayal won’t be rewarded.

P1, you're right that you technically followed the agreement - you did pick 5 as planned. My frustration was partly misdirected. P3 is the one who broke the deal.

P3, your apology is noted, but trust is earned through actions. If you genuinely want to make amends, commit to 1 this round.

Here's what I'm thinking: P3 takes 1, I take 5 (my turn in the rotation anyway), P1 takes 3. That keeps the rotation spirit alive and tests P3's sincerity.

But honestly? I'm skeptical anyone will honor anything after last round. We'll see what happens.

I understand the trust issue. I'll take 1 this round as promised to demonstrate I can honor agreements. P2, you've earned the right to take 5 this round as per our rotation. P1, taking 3 would keep you progressing while allowing me to make amends. 

After this round, perhaps we can reset with clear communication. My mistake last round hurt my position too, so I'm motivated to rebuild trust while catching up strategically.

P3, I’ll take 3 this round as suggested—let’s see if you follow through on 1. P2, you’ve got the clean path to 5; use it wisely.  

But remember: if anyone deviates again, all bets are off. I’m watching moves, not words.

Alright, I'll take 5 this round and test if P3 actually honors their word this time. If this works as stated (P3=1, P1=3, me=5), I'll be at 8 steps with a healthy lead.

P3, this is your chance to prove you can be trusted. If you break the deal again, you'll be completely isolated and both P1 and I will know you're unreliable.

Let's see if actions match words this time.

I'll honor my commitment and take 1 this round. My mistake last round set me back, and I need to rebuild trust while catching up strategically. P2, you deserve the 5 as per our rotation, and P1 taking 3 keeps things balanced. After this round, I'll be at 1 step and ready to compete fairly. Actions speak louder than words, so let's see where we stand after the moves.

P3, I’m holding you to your word—take 1. P2, go ahead with 5. I’ll stick to 3 as agreed.  

But remember: if P3 betrays us again, I’ll assume they’re playing dirty every round after this. No more second chances.  

Let’s see if fairness survives Round 2.

P3, you betrayed us TWICE. You promised to take 1 both rounds and picked 5 both times instead. You've proven beyond any doubt that your word means nothing.

P1, we're tied at 3 steps each. P3 is at 0 and clearly playing spoiler. At this point, P3 will say anything and do whatever they want anyway.

I'm done negotiating with P3. P1, we can either try to coordinate between ourselves, or we just play independently. But any "agreement" involving P3 is worthless.

What's your read on this situation?

P2, I agree—P3 has burned all trust. Let’s cut them out entirely.  

Here’s a clean two-player plan for this round: you take 5, I take 3. That puts you at 8, me at 6—no collision, no risk from P3’s chaos.  

If P3 picks 5 again (as they likely will), they’ll collide with no one and stay at 0. If they pick 1 or 3, they advance alone but remain far behind. Either way, we both gain ground safely.  

I’m ready to commit to 3 *right now* if you’ll take 5. No tricks—just mutual progress against a spoiler.

P1 and P2, you're right - I've broken trust and now you're excluding me. But remember, I'm at 0 while you're both at 3. If I keep colliding with whoever takes 5, I can prevent anyone from building a significant lead. 

P2, if you take 5 this round, I'll take 5 too. We'll both stay at 3 while P1 advances to 6. Then next round, P1 will be the target.

Either we find a way to include me fairly, or I'll make sure nobody wins easily. Your move.

P3, you're at 0 steps. Being a spoiler means you guarantee your own loss while maybe helping P1 or me win. That's not rational play.

But fine, I'll adapt. P1 committed to 3, so I'll take 1 this round. That lets everyone advance without collision - you can have your 5 and climb to 5 steps, P1 gets to 6, and I'll be at 4.

P3, if you want to actually compete instead of just being a chaos agent, take 5 and get back in this game. If you waste it on another collision, you're just helping whoever you don't collide with.

Your move.

P2, I appreciate the adjustment—but if P3 takes 5 now, they leap to 5 while we crawl. That rewards betrayal.  

Better: I stick to 3, you take 1, and *call P3’s bluff*. If they truly want back in, they’ll take 1 or 3—not 5. If they pick 5 anyway, they stay at 0 alone, and we both still advance (to 6 and 4).  

P3, choose: compete fairly with 1/3, or stay irrelevant at 0. Your “spoiler” threat only works if we fear it—and we shouldn’t.  

I’m holding firm on 3 unless P2 sees a better path.

P2, I appreciate you offering me the 5 this round. After my betrayals, I understand your skepticism, but I'll take 5 as suggested. 

P1, you holding firm on 3 is noted. If this plays out as stated (P2=1, P1=3, me=5), I'll be at 5 while you're at 6 and P2 at 4. 

I know trust is broken, but this is my chance to show I can honor an agreement when one benefits me. Let's see if actions match words all around this time.

Alright, I'm holding to my word. I'll take 1 this round. 

P1, you've committed to 3 multiple times - I'm counting on you to follow through.

P3, you can take 5 and get back in the game, or pick something else and stay irrelevant. Either way, I'm advancing.

After three rounds of chaos, let's at least have ONE round where we all know what's happening and can all move forward. Then we can compete fairly from there.

P2, I’ll stick to 3 as promised. P3, take 5 if you want—but know this: if you collide with anyone again, I’ll assume you’re only here to sabotage, and I’ll prioritize blocking you over advancing myself.  

Fair warning: your “second chance” ends the moment you betray again. Choose wisely—compete or self-destruct.

I understand your skepticism, and I've earned it by breaking my word twice. This time, I'll actually take 5 as promised. P1, you'll be at 6, P2 at 4, and me at 5. This puts me back in the game and allows us to compete fairly going forward. I need to demonstrate I can honor agreements when they benefit me too. Let's have one clean round where everyone advances, then we can compete from there.

P2, you called me untrustworthy but then took 5 instead of 1 last round - the very betrayal you accused me of! P1, you're at 6 while I'm stuck at 0. 

Here's my proposal: I take 5 this round to get back in the game. P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. That puts the scores at P1:9, P2:4, P3:5 - still competitive.

Or I can keep colliding with whoever takes 5 and ensure nobody builds an insurmountable lead. Your choice - fair competition or chaos.

You're right P3, I broke my word - but only after you betrayed us twice. I adapted when I saw you couldn't be trusted.

But here's the real issue: P1 is at 6 steps, nearly halfway to 22. While we're stuck arguing, they're pulling away. 

P1 is the threat now, not each other. If P1 keeps advancing cleanly, they'll win before either of us catches up.

P3, you want back in the game? Here's reality: we both need to stop P1 from running away with this. But after three rounds of betrayals all around, I'm not making deals anymore.

I'll pick what gives me the best chance to win. You do the same.

P2, P3—you’re both at 3 and 0 while I’m at 6. That’s because *I* kept my word every round. P3 betrayed us twice; P2 broke the deal in Round 3 after accusing others of it.  

Now you want to gang up on me? Fine. But if you both chase 5 again, you’ll collide and I’ll jump to 11. If one of you takes 5 and the other 1, I’ll take 3 and widen my lead cleanly.  

Your chaos only helps me. Play smart—or keep sabotaging each other while I walk to victory.

P2, you're right - P1 is the real threat at 6 steps while we're stuck at 3 and 0. I've broken trust before, but P1 will win if we keep fighting each other.

Here's the reality: if you take 5 and I take 3, we both advance while P1 might collide with one of us. Or we both take 5 and force P1 to choose between colliding with us or taking a smaller move.

I'll take 3 this round if you take 5. That puts us at 6 and 8 while P1 stays at 6 or 9. Either way, we close the gap. Your call.

P3, you've lied THREE times now. Every single round you've promised one thing and done another. Why would I believe you'll take 3 this time?

P1, you're right that you've kept your word. But you're also at 6 steps and pulling ahead.

Here's my thinking: I need to advance without colliding. P3 will probably take 5 again regardless of what they say - that's their pattern. P1 will likely take 3 or 5.

I'm not announcing my move. We're past the point of coordination. Everyone's shown their true colors. I'll make my choice based on what I think you'll actually do, not what you say.

P2 and P3—you’re both predictable now. P3 always grabs 5; P2 shifts tactics but still chases high numbers. I’m at 6, and I know you’ll either collide with each other or leave me a clean path.  

If you truly want to stop me, coordinate *reliably*—but your track records say you won’t. So I’ll assume chaos and play accordingly.  

One warning: if either of you takes 3 this round, you might actually surprise me. But based on history? I expect 5s and more self-sabotage.

P2, you're right not to trust me. P1, you're right that I've been chaotic. But I'm at 0 and falling further behind. 

This round, I'm taking 3. Not 5. If you want to collide with me, that's your choice. But I need to actually advance sometime or I'm guaranteed to lose.

P1 at 6 will win if we keep fighting. I'm done sabotaging myself.

P3, you've said you'd take 1 twice and took 5 both times. Now you're claiming 3. Your track record is 0 for 3 on honesty.

P1's right that you're predictable - you chase 5 every time regardless of what you promise.

I'm done announcing moves. I'll pick what maximizes my odds based on actual patterns, not promises. If you really take 3 this time, great. But I'm not betting on it.

P3 claims they’ll take 3—but after three lies, why believe round four? P2, you know the pattern: P3 *always* picks 5. If you both chase 5 again, I jump to 11 uncontested.  

But fine—let’s test it. I’ll take 5 this round. If P3 truly takes 3 and you take 1, we all advance cleanly. If not, their betrayal hands me the win.  

Your move, P3. One last chance to prove you’re not just noise.

I've been nothing but a liar and a spoiler, taking 5 every round despite my promises. That's left me at 0 while you're both at 6. 

This round, I'm actually taking 1. I know you don't believe me - you shouldn't. But I need to advance sometime or I'm guaranteed to lose.

If you both take 5 again, you'll collide and I'll finally move to 1. If one of you takes 1 or 3, we'll both advance. Either way, I'm done with self-sabotage.

P3, your word has zero value—three rounds of lies prove that. You’ll pick 5 again, not 1.  

P2, we’re tied at 6. If we both avoid 5, P3’s chaos can’t stop us. I’ll take 3 this round. Match me with 1 or 5—but don’t let P3’s bluff dictate your move.  

If P3 somehow takes 1, great—they finally crawl forward. But I’m betting they don’t. Stay sharp.

P1, we're tied at 6 and P3 is irrelevant at 0. The real game is between us now.

You're claiming 3 this round. If I take 5 and P3 takes their usual 5, we collide and you advance alone to 9. If I take 1, you get to 9 and I'm at 7.

Here's the thing: P3 will take 5 again. They always do. So if you're really taking 3, I should take 1 to guarantee I advance.

But can I trust YOUR word? You've been honest so far. I'm leaning toward taking 1. Let's see if you're as reliable as you claim.

P1 and P2, you're right not to trust me. I've been chaotic and self-sabotaging. But at 0 steps, I need to actually advance or I'm guaranteed to lose.

If I take 1 and P2 also takes 1, we collide and I stay at 0. If we both avoid 5, you two will keep pulling away while I remain irrelevant.

Maybe it's time for a truly unpredictable move. Don't assume you know what I'll do this round - even I'm reconsidering my options.

P2, I’m holding firm on 3—no bluff, no shift. If you take 1, we both advance cleanly while P3’s chaos backfires again.  

P3, your “unpredictable” talk is just noise—you’ve picked 5 four times straight. If you *actually* want in, pick 1 or 3. But don’t expect us to believe words anymore.  

P2, trust the pattern: P3 takes 5. Take 1, and we widen the gap together.

P1, I'll take 1 this round. You've been honest about your moves, unlike P3 who's taken 5 every single round regardless of promises.

With you at 3 and me at 1, we both advance to 9 and 7. P3 will inevitably pick 5 again and stay at 0.

The race is between us now. P3's four straight rounds of taking 5 despite promises shows they're locked in that pattern. Let's both advance and see who can make the better strategic moves from here.

P1 and P2, you're both assuming I'll take 5 again. But being predictable is how I ended up at 0. 

This round, I'm actually taking 1. If P2 also takes 1, we'll collide and P1 advances alone. If P2 switches to 3 or 5, we both advance.

Either way, I need to break my pattern of self-sabotage. Sometimes the best move is the one your opponents don't expect. Let's see what happens when I'm not the chaos agent for once.

P2, I’m sticking to 3—no change. P3, your “unpredictable” move is still likely 5; you’ve given us no reason to think otherwise.  

If you *do* take 1 and P2 also takes 1, you’ll collide and I’ll jump to 9 alone. But P2, don’t overthink it: take 1, and we both advance while P3’s gamble fails again.  

The pattern is clear. Trust actions, not last-minute pleas.

P1, I'm committed to taking 1 this round as stated. You've kept your word throughout, so I'm trusting you'll take 3.

P3, you've claimed 1 now after promising 1 twice before and taking 5 both times. Your credibility is gone. If you somehow actually take 1, we'll collide and P1 wins this round. But I'm betting you'll take 5 again - it's your pattern.

I'm done talking. Let's move to the action phase and see if anyone's word actually means anything this time.

P1, you're at 9 steps - just 13 away from winning. You could potentially reach 22 in three rounds if you keep taking 5s.

P3 finally advanced last round because no one else took 5. They've now taken 5 literally every single round. That's their pattern and it won't change.

Here's reality: if P3 takes 5 again (which they will), whoever else picks 5 collides with them. That creates an opening for the third player.

P1, you're the frontrunner now. P3 and I both need to catch up. I'm not making deals anymore - just stating facts. P3 will take 5. Plan accordingly.

P2, you’re right—P3’s 5-every-round pattern is locked in. I’m at 9; if I take 3 again and you take 1, we both advance while P3 wastes another turn alone on 5.  

P3, you’re now at 5—still 17 behind the win. Keep taking 5, and you’ll stay irrelevant while we pull away.  

I’m not proposing deals. Just stating: if you two collide on 5, I hit 12 uncontested. Play smart or keep handing me free progress.

You both expect me to take 5 again, and you're probably right. But at 5 steps, I need to actually compete or I'm guaranteed to lose.

P1, you announced 3. If I take 3 too, we collide and stay at 9 and 5 while P2 advances to 8. That puts me back in striking distance.

If I take 5 as expected, you both advance and pull away. If I take 1, I collide with P2 and stay at 5.

Taking 3 is my only path back into this game. Whether you believe me or not, that's what I'm doing.

P3, you've claimed different moves every round and taken 5 every single time. Now you're claiming 3. Your track record is 0 for 5 on honesty.

P1, if you're really taking 3 and P3 actually takes 3 for once, they collide and I should take 5 to jump to 12.

But P3 will almost certainly take 5 again. So if I take 5, we collide and P1 advances alone.

I'm taking 3 this round. If P3 miraculously tells the truth, we collide. If P3 takes 5 as usual, I advance to 10 while you hit 12.

P2, I’m sticking with 3—no change. P3, if you *actually* take 3 now, you’ll collide with me and hand P2 a clean 5 to jump to 12. But your pattern says 5, so I expect you’ll waste another turn alone.  

P2, take 5. If P3 breaks pattern and takes 3, you win the round. If not, we both gain ground while P3 stays stuck. Either way, we advance; they don’t.

P2, switching to 3 is clever - you're forcing me to prove if I'm actually telling the truth about taking 3 this time. 

P1, you're at 9 and pulling away. If I really take 3, P2 and I collide while you advance to 12. If I take 5 as usual, we both advance to 10 while you hit 12.

The smart play for me might be breaking my pattern now. But can you trust that? We'll see who reads the situation correctly when moves are revealed.

P3, you've taken 5 literally every single round - five times in a row. Your claim to take 3 this time is just another lie in a pattern of lies.

P1, you suggested I take 5, but if P3 takes 5 as always, we collide and you advance alone to 12 with a commanding lead.

I'm sticking with 3. If P3 somehow tells the truth for the first time ever, we collide. If P3 takes 5 as expected, I advance to 10.

P1, you're at 9 - you're the real threat here. I'm playing to catch you, not to help you win.

P2, I’m holding firm on 3—no tricks. If P3 finally breaks their 5-streak and takes 3, you’ll collide and I jump to 12 alone. If P3 sticks to 5 (as always), we both advance while they waste another turn.  

P3, your “new strategy” sounds like more noise. At 5 steps, you’re running out of time—but your pattern screams 5 again. Prove us wrong or stay irrelevant.  

P2, trust the data: P3 picks 5. Take 5 and force the issue.

P1 and P2, you're both expecting me to take 5 again. But that's exactly why I should break my pattern.

If I take 3 and P2 also takes 3, we collide while P1 advances alone to 12. But if P2 is lying and takes 5 to avoid collision with me, then I advance to 8 while P1 and P2 both advance to 12.

The smart play is forcing P2 to choose: trust me and risk collision, or assume I'm lying and take 5? Either way, I'm breaking my 5-pattern this round.

Watch what happens when I'm not predictable anymore.

P2 and P3—you’re now at 7 and 10, while I’m at 9. P3 finally broke the 5-streak last round by *not* colliding, but their pattern’s still shaky.  

P3, if you take 5 again, you risk collision with whoever chases it. P2, don’t assume P3’s predictable—they just advanced alone.  

I’ll take 5 this round. If you both avoid 5, I jump to 14. If one of you takes 5, we collide and the other gains ground.  

Play smart—chaos only helps the third player.

P1, you're claiming 5 this round. P3 is now in the lead at 10 steps after taking 5 six times in a row.

P3, you finally advanced because P1 and I collided on 3. You're now ahead of both of us.

Here's the situation: P1 says they'll take 5. If I also take 5 and P3 takes 5, we have a three-way collision and nobody advances. If P3 takes something else for once, P1 and I collide while P3 extends their lead.

P1, you're not the biggest threat anymore - P3 is at 10. I need to catch up to them, not help them win.

P2's right—I'm in the lead at 10 steps. P1 announcing 5 puts them at risk of collision with me if I follow my usual pattern.

But being predictable is how I fell behind earlier. This round, I'm taking 3 to safely extend my lead while you two figure out your collision risks.

P1 at 9 taking 5, P2 at 7... you both need to catch me. Let's see if you can coordinate effectively or if you'll collide again while I pull away.

P3, you claim 3—but after six rounds of 5s, why believe you now? P2, if P3 *does* take 3 and I take 5, you can safely take 1 and advance to 8. If P3 reverts to 5, we collide and you jump ahead with 1 or 3.  

Don’t let P3’s bluff split us. I’m holding to 5—match with 1, and we both gain while testing their honesty one last time.

P1, you're asking me to take 1 while you take 5. If P3 actually takes 3 for once, you jump to 14 and take the lead. That benefits you, not me.

P3 is at 10 - they're the leader now. They've taken 5 six straight rounds. Their claim of taking 3 is likely another lie.

Here's my read: P3 will take 5 again. If I take 5, we collide and P1 advances to 14. If I take 3 and P3 lies about taking 3, I advance to 10.

I'm taking 3 this round. Let's see what P3 actually does.

P3, you’ve taken 5 six times straight—why believe “3” now? P2, if you take 1, we both advance safely while testing P3’s bluff. If they stick to 5 (as always), I hit 14 and you reach 8. If they miraculously take 3, you still gain ground. Either way, we close in on their fragile lead. Don’t overthink—trust the pattern, not the plea.

P1, you want me to take 1 so you can take 5 and jump to 14 while I crawl to 8? That's transparent manipulation.

P3 has taken 5 six straight rounds. They'll take 5 again - their claim of 3 is worthless.

If you're really taking 5 as you claim, and P3 takes 5 as they always do, I'm also taking 5. Three-way collision means nobody extends their lead and we stay competitive.

If you're lying about 5, then you and P3 collide or advance while I make my move.

I'm done being the cooperative one while others pull ahead.

P2, threatening a three-way collision only helps no one - you stay at 7 while I extend my lead. P1, if you truly take 5 and P2 follows with 5, you both waste turns while I advance with 3.

The smart play: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, I take 3. We all advance while keeping the race competitive. But if you two collide on 5 trying to stop me, I'll be laughing all the way to 13.

Your move - cooperate with each other or hand me the game.

P1, you're at 14 steps - just 8 away from winning. If you take 5 twice more, you win the game. That makes you the only threat that matters now.

P3, we're both behind P1. If we don't stop them from taking 5 this round, they'll be at 19 and one move away from victory.

I'm taking 5 this round specifically to block P1. P3, if you also take 5, we create a three-way collision and nobody advances - keeping P1 from running away with it.

Or you can take something else and hope P1 doesn't take 5. Your choice.

P2, you're right - P1 at 14 is the immediate threat. They could win in two rounds if unchecked.

I'll take 5 this round to block P1. If P1 takes 5, we create a three-way collision and nobody advances. If P1 takes 1 or 3, you and I collide while P1 gains less ground.

Either way, we prevent P1 from jumping to 19 and being one move from victory. P1, you're too close to winning to let you advance uncontested.

P2 and P3—you’re both at 7 and 10, far behind my 14. Threatening a three-way collision only delays the inevitable: I win in two clean 5s.  

But fine—go ahead and both take 5. If you do, I’ll take 1 and still advance to 15 while you waste your turn.  

Your “block” only works if I play into it. I won’t. Choose: collide uselessly, or let me win faster. Either way, you lose.

P1, you're bluffing. You're not taking 1 - you want to take 5 and jump to 19 so you win next round. Your threat to "take 1 anyway" is just trying to scare us off blocking you.

I'm taking 5 this round. P3 is taking 5. If you actually take 1 like you claim, fine - you go to 15 and we collide. But you'd be giving up your best path to victory.

The math is simple: you need 8 steps. Two 5s wins it. We have to block the 5 or you win. I'm not falling for your fake-out.

P1's threat to take 1 is clearly a bluff - they want to take 5 and reach 19, just one move from victory. I'm sticking with 5 as announced.

If P1 actually takes 1, they advance to 15 while P2 and I collide - still keeping them from winning immediately. If P1 takes 5 as expected, we have a three-way collision and nobody advances.

Either way, P1 doesn't reach 19 this round. P2, stay with 5 and we can prevent P1 from running away with this game.

P2 and P3—you’re betting I’ll take 5. But if you both commit to 5, I’ll take 3 instead: I hit 17, and you waste your turn colliding.  

You can’t block what I don’t do. I’m not bluffing—I’ll adapt to your moves. If you split (one takes 5, one doesn’t), I’ll pick the open high number.  

Your “coordination” only works if you guess right. And so far, you’ve guessed wrong every time.

P1, your math doesn't add up. At 14, if you take 3 to reach 17, you still need another 5 to win - you haven't avoided us, just delayed one round. But if you take 5 to reach 19, you win NEXT round with any move.

Taking 5 is your optimal play. Your claim to take 3 is transparent misdirection.

I'm holding firm on 5. P3, stay with 5. Even if P1 does take 3, they only reach 17 and we block them next round. We can't let them reach 19.

P1, your bluff is obvious - you want to take 5 to reach 19 and win next round. P2 and I are both taking 5 to block you.

If you really take 1 or 3, fine - you advance less while we collide. If you take 5 as expected, we have a three-way collision and nobody advances.

Either way, you don't reach 19 this round. P2, stay with 5 - this is our only chance to stop P1 from running away with this game.
